posts.title: Google agrees to pay $28m in racial bias lawsuit
top_comments:
From the article: "The practice of basing starting pay and job level on prior salaries reinforced historical race and ethnicity-based disparities, according to Ms Cantu's lawyers."

Wouldn't that mean Google inherited the employee's last employer's valuation of them as human resources?

I'm surprised they settled. Google would likely prevail on the merits of the case, because they definitely don't discriminate pay based on race.

*Especially* in the past decade, when they've gotten extremely rigid and formulaic about standardizing pay. Google has extremely tight pay bands and its comp structure targets is extremely formulaic, depending almost entirely location (targetting something like the 90th percentile of total comp amongst peer companies in a given location => SF Bay Area / NYC have a higher premium than say, somewhere in the midwest US) and level. Crucially, those formulas don't include anything about race.

The targets are so formulaic and standardized such that when you reach the cap for your level / location, you won't get any more yearly merit increases even if you performance would otherwise merit it. The only thing you can do once you cap out is hope the target for your pay band moves up, e.g., due to that "90th percentile among peers in your local market" metric going up b/c of inflation or pay competition among local employers.

What is true and what's likley happening, since the suit is about "starting pay" is probably a few counfounding variables. While your band is fixed by level and locatiohn, your starting place in your band can vary depending on your negotiations—did you have competing offers, how strong were they, what was your hiring committee rating (hire / strong hire), did you even attempt to negotiate, etc.?

So I could see variability in *starting pay* due to confounding variables like working in lower cost of living areas, not negotiating as strongly, not having as many or high competing offers, lower hire rating, etc. But that's all about negotiations and interview performance. Definitely not due to race.
